q.t: The diagram shows a road where vehicles travel at high speeds. Markings painted on the road surface are spaced 40 m apart. Drivers are advised to keep at least two markings visible on the road between them and the vehicle in front. 40 m

p.t: The maximum speed vehicles travel at on the road is 110 km/hr. The table shows data from a driving manual for a vehicle travelling on a straight, horizontal road. Speed (km/hr) Braking distance (m) Stopping distance (m) 110 75 96
(i) Calculate the maximum speed v of vehicles on the road in S.I. units. v = Unit =
A vehicle passes over one of the markings. Calculate time taken to travel the 40 m distance between the two markings. t = s
Using the table, explain why having markings 40 m apart helps prevent collisions

A vehicle with mass 1600 kg is travelling at 110 km / hr. The driver sees an obstruction and applies the brakes to bring the vehicle to rest in 5.6 s. (i) Estimate the magnitude of the average resultant force F required to bring the vehicle to rest. F = N
Explain the effect on the distance required to bring the vehicle to rest if the road has an upwards slope

p.t: 35Â°7.8 m rad sâ€“1Ï‰11.1m rod seatdisc To test the equipment a sandbag is attached to the seat and the ride is started. The combined mass of the seat and the sandbag is 12 kg. The rod makes an angle of 35Â° with the vertical.
(i) Draw an arrow labelled T on the diagram to represent the tension in the rod.
Show that the radius of the circular path followed by the sandbag is about 10 m.

Using your answer to (a)(iv), determine the horizontal displacement s travelled by the sandbag before hitting the ground. s = m

q.t: A student is attempting to determine the value of g, the acceleration due to gravity, by two different methods. Method 1. Vertical drop method Measuring the time of fall of a small dense ball being dropped from rest from different heights. Method 2. Rolling ball method Measuring the time it takes for the same ball to roll 1.900 m down a ramp, set at different angles. Single sets of results are shown below. The times were measured using a standard stopwatch operated by the student. Compare and discuss the uncertainties of the two values of g that could be obtained using these single measurements. Describe how the student would analyse both sets of data when a full range of results has been taken. Vertical drop method Drop height / m Time taken / s 1.20 0.50 Rolling ball method Length of ramp / m Angle / Â° Time taken / s 1.900 30 0.90 Additional space if required

parts.raw: Level 3 (5â€“6 marks) Detailed quantitative discussion and comparison of uncertainties, and clear description of graphical analysis There is a well-developed line of reasoning which is clear and logically structured. The information presented is relevant and substantiated. Level 2 (3â€“4 marks) Some quantitative discussion of uncertainty for one method and clear description of graphical analysis Or Discussion, with some quantitative ideas and comparison of uncertainty for both methods with some graphical analysis There is a line of reasoning presented with some structure. The information presented is in the most part relevant and supported by some evidence. Level 1 (1â€“2 marks) Incomplete discussion of uncertainty with no comparison Or Description of analysis There is an attempt at a logical structure with a line of reasoning. The information is in the most part relevant.B1 x 6Use level of response annotations in RM Assessor Indicative scientific points may include: Discussion of uncertainty â— No repeat makes experiment inherently uncertain â— Height +/- 1cm â— Ramp length +/- 1mm â— Resolution/â€precisionâ€ of stopclock is 0.01s, but reaction time is much greater â— Times +/- 0.1 s (or more) â— Calculation of g will use time squared so double the percentage uncertainty in t â— Angle likely to be +/- 1 or 2 degrees â— Ramp calculation uses sine of angle, so difficult to quantify the uncertainty as a percentage to combine with other variables Comparison â— Ramp method has greater time and length both greater so smaller percentage uncertainties â— Frictional effects ramp method more â— More difficult to measure times for drop â— Uncertainty for height and ramp different Analysis â— Ignore references to comparisons of the value of g found from both methods â— Find g from s= Â½ a t2for multiple values of s and average H556/01 Mark Scheme June 2023 Question Answer Mark Guidance

p.t: A sealed container contains n moles of an ideal gas. The gas has pressure p, absolute temperature T and occupies volume V. The mass of one mole of the gas is M. Use an ideal gas equation to show that the density Ï of the gas is given by the expression Ï = pM RT.

An airship has a cabin suspended underneath a gasbag inflated with helium. The airship is floating above the ground and is stationary. The volume of the gasbag is 12 000 m3. The temperature of the helium and the surrounding air is 20 Â°C. Atmospheric pressure is 1.0 Ã— 105 Pa. The molar mass of air is 0.029 kg molâ€“1. The volume of the cabin is negligible compared to the volume of the gasbag.
Show that the density of air under the conditions described is about 1.2 kg mâ€“3.
Calculate the weight of air displaced by the airship. weight of air N
Explain why the weight of air displaced by the airship has the same magnitude as the weight of the airship and its contents
The pressure of the helium in the gasbag is maintained at a value only slightly greater than atmospheric pressure. Suggest why a larger pressure is not used

The airship engine drives a fan which moves 7.8 kg of air per second at a relative speed of 45 m s â€“1, so the airship starts to move. All other conditions given in (b) remain the same. Calculate the thrust that the engine produces. thrust N
The airship has a higher maximum speed at high altitudes, but also produces less thrust from the engine. Explain these observations

p.t: Fig. 21.1 shows a stationary glider of mass m on an air track. The glider has identical springs with force constant k attached to each end which are secured to fixed posts. The air track blower is turned on and the glider is displaced a small distance x0, as seen in Fig. 21.2 . It is then released. The glider moves horizontally in simple harmonic motion. The springs remain in tension throughout the motion. The time taken for 20 complete oscillations is measured, and the period T calculated. Fig. 21.1 Fig. 21.2 air trackfixed postfixed post fixed postglider at equilibriumx0 The relationship between the period T, the mass of the glider m and the force constant k is described by the equation T 2 = 2Ï€2m k.
Show that the equation above is homogeneous by reducing the equation to SI base units. Describe two different errors in the table. 1 2

Explain why the magnitude of the resultant force F on the glider is given by F = 2kx where x is the displacement at any time Plot the first data point from the table on the graph below. The other points have all been plotted. The table of results is repeated on the opposite page. Include on your graph a line of best fit. 0 0.200 0.400 0.600 0.8000.2000.4000.6000.8001.000 T2/ s2 m/ kgPMT m / kg 20T / s T T 2 0.200 12.2 0.61 0.372 0.300 13.6 0.68 0.462 0.400 15.6 0.78 0.608 0.500 17.6 0.88 0.774 0.600 18.9 0.945 0.893 0.700 20.0 1 1
State and explain the effect, if any, of increasing the initial displacement on the period of the subsequent motion Use the graph to determine the value of k. k = N mâ€“1

Masses are added to the glider, and the measurement of 20T repeated. The results table is below. m / kg 20T / s T T 2 0.200 12.2 0.61 0.372 0.300 13.6 0.68 0.462 0.400 15.6 0.78 0.608 0.500 17.6 0.88 0.774 0.600 18.9 0.945 0.893 0.700 20.0 1 1
When the initial displacement is increased, one spring increases its extension while the extension of the other spring decreases. Explain why the maximum kinetic energy of the motion increases

q.t: A star has a mass similar to that of the Sun. Describe how the position of this star on a Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram changes as it evolves. Fig. 22.1 is a blank H-R diagram. You may add information to Fig. 22.1 as part of your response. Fig. 22.2 shows the relative intensities of different wavelengths of light in the spectrum of a star. Explain how information from Fig. 22.2 could be used to suggest the stage of evolution of the star. Describe the limitations of the analysis. Fig. 22.1 luminosity temperature Fig. 22.2 0relative intensity wavelength Additional space if required

q.t: The Hipparcos space telescope used stellar parallax with a precision of 9.7 Ã— 10â€“4 arcseconds to determine the distance to stars. One of the stars studied was Polaris A. Data about this star is in the table below. Parallax angle 7.5 Ã— 10â€“3 arcseconds Radius 2.1 Ã— 1010 m Mass 1.1 Ã— 1031 kg Surface temperature 6000 K Temperature of the atmosphere of the star 4.0 Ã— 106 K

p.t: (i) Estimate the maximum stellar distance in parsecs that could be measured using Hipparcos. maximum stellar distance = pc
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the calculated value of the distance to Polaris A. percentage uncertainty = %

A continuous stream of particles called a solar wind flows from the surface of the star into the surrounding space. These particles include helium nuclei of mass 6.6 Ã— 10 â€“27 kg. Assume that the atmosphere is modelled as an ideal gas.
Show that the typical kinetic energy of a helium nucleus in the atmosphere is about 10 â€“16 J.

The gravitational potential energy of a helium nucleus in the outer layer of the star is â€“2.3 Ã— 10â€“16 J. Calculate the gravitational potential energy U at the maximum distance from the star that a helium nucleus could reach. U = J
Calculate the distance from the centre of the star reached by this helium nucleus. distance = m
